awd_titl_txt: RAPID: Fire-mediated natural experiment on top-down versus bottom-up forces on a vertebrate community
awd_abstract_narration:
One of the most longstanding questions in ecology is the degree to which food availability and predation determine the identity and abundance of animals in ecological communities. When food resources are transferred into ecosystems it is especially difficult to determine the effect of predation on local prey species abundance. Predator abundance may increase, leading to decreased local prey density, or predators may specialize on imported resources and have little effect on local prey density. In the Pantanal wetlands of Brazil jaguars specialize on imported aquatic prey and have the most picivorous diet of any terrestrial obligate carnivore. Moreover, in this unusual Pantanal food web jaguars, the apex predator, are by far the most abundant terrestrial mammal species. However, it is unclear if the low density of large herbivores is due to low available food resources (bottom-up control) or predation especially by the abundant jaguars (top-down control). Catastrophic wildfires in September 2020 removed canopy vegetation from about 30% of the Pantanal and about 50% of the PI’s previously established study sites at Taiama, a protected area in the Pantanal. Canopy removal stimulates a flush of nutritious early seral vegetation. By comparing mammalian herbivore abundance in burned and unburned areas, and before and after the fire, the PI will be able to determine if this food web is controlled by top-down or bottom-up forces. This project lies at the heart of the land-use/climate change nexus in the Mato Grosso region of Brazil, the world's largest soy and bovine beef exporter. Understanding the dynamics of this system is critical as fires in the Pantanal are widely predicted to become more frequent and increasingly severe due to both climate change and large-scale cropland encroachment. In addition, this work will contribute to the education of a graduate student and further an ongoing collaboration between US and Brazilian scientists.
  
The PIs will use a before–after-control–impact (BACI) design to ask whether (1) jaguars specializing on aquatic prey have reduced predation pressure on terrestrial species, or (2) whether aquatic subsidies to jaguars lead to increased predation that suppresses mammalian herbivore populations. Comparison of 4-years of pre-fire data to post-fire data (before-after impact), as well as unburnt and burnt areas (control-impact) within the reserve, will allow the PI to determine if the food web in which the jaguar is the apex carnivore is mediated by top-down or bottom-up forces. The PIs will quantify vegetation regeneration, terrestrial and aquatic prey species abundance, and jaguar density and diet for one year starting in September 2021 (one year after the fires). Fast regenerative growth is typical in this region making the timing of the proposed study critical.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The transfer of food resources between terrestrial and aquatic ecosystems can strongly influence wildlife communities. Terrestrial carnivores can suppress land-based prey populations in particular if they are also supported by an abundant aquatic prey species. However, the carnivore may instead choose to focus only on aquatic prey and thereby relieve predation pressure on terrestrial prey populations. Perhaps one of the most famous examples of this are the hyperabundant brown bears feeding on salmon in coastal Alaska. The goal of this study was to better understand how aquatic resources can affect terrestrial predator-prey interactions and to also shed light on how uncharacteristic wildfire events may shape these dynamics. The intensity and frequency of droughts and wildfires are predicted to increase in tropical ecosystems introducing new stressors on wildlife communities. It is currently unclear how these natural or anthropogenic disturbances will impact predator-prey interactions. Specifically, we wanted to understand how jaguars that are specialized in aquatic prey (fish and alligators) may affect terrestrial herbivore populations in a protected area in Pantanal, Brazil.

Pantanal is the largest continental wetland in the world and is famous for its biodiversity. In September 2020, catastrophic wildfires burned over 4.5 million hectares of the Pantanal wetland, approximately 30% of the entire biome, the largest event of this kind in recorded history. In the years prior to the fire we used camera traps to study jaguars and their prey in Taiama Ecological Station in northern Pantanal. Surprisingly, jaguars, the top predator, was the most frequently observed mammal and large herbivores such as capybara, tapir or deer which are common in neighboring areas, were rarely seen. We wanted to disentangle whether the low abundance of herbivores was due to predation by the jaguar population that is supported by aquatic prey, or if the herbivores were limited by a lack of food resources. Fire can increase the amount of palatable understory vegetation by removing canopy cover and thereby increasing sunlight. The catastrophic wildfires that hit Pantanal therefore produced a unique and fleeting opportunity for us to assess whether this biome is top-down or bottom-up regulated by comparing animal abundances (jaguars and herbivores) in burnt versus unburnt areas in pre-fire and post-fire years.

We found an increase in the number of herbivore species and camera detections one year after the fire, however this increasing trend began before the 2020 fires. Jaguars remained the most frequently detected mammal in Taiama every year indicating that predation did not limit herbivores since their numbers increased despite jaguar abundance remaining high. It is not clear that herbivores were bottom-up limited either since the increase in detections began before the fire that would have caused an influx of new vegetation. Jaguars continued to be specialized on aquatic prey despite the increase in terrestrial herbivores post-fire. We speculate that the increasing trend in the number of terrestrial mammal species is due to the ongoing drought in Pantanal. As the nearby upland areas are getting drier, animals move to the floodplains in search of water. Our findings highlight how disturbances can influence animal communities and predator-prey interactions.
